- a review of the "Horror on the Orient Express" campaign (Call of Cthulhu) by players who mastered this enormous journey

- an article about Lovecraft inspired movies

- Cops: out-of-the-box Shadownrun charakters and how to play them

- an article about zombies (before they went mainstream) and their appearance in movies, games and longdrink glasses

188388.name: The Wild West (D6)
188388.description:
User summary:

The Wild West is a very simple role-playing game that focuses almost exclusively on firearms combat during the frontier period of the American West. Characters have four Attributes (Strength, Stamina, Smarts, and Speed) and have ten dice distributed among them, with a minimum of 1D and a maximum of 4D. These dice are rolled as a pool whenever the character attempts some action with that Attribute. Characters also have one or more Skills among which thirteen dice are distributed. The game lists eleven "Primary Skills" which must utilize at least seven dice. Characters may have any Secondary Skill the player desires. Most Primary Skills deal with combat: Six Shooter, Rifle, Blade, Fists, Ride, Lasso, Whip, Tracking, Stealth, Ingine Speak, and Gambling.

Action resolution is performed by rolling a D6 dice pool based on either a Skill or an Attribute. Odd results are considered successes. Combat works essentially the same way though it transpires in rounds of limited time and supports initiative.

A printable character sheet in RTF format also is available for download.

188389.description:
The arena is ready and the excited crowd is eagerly awaiting the spectacle of the Dragon Master duel. Who will win the contest to become the new member of the honorable Dragon Master guild?

Using both the Dragon Master base game and the Dragon Master: BGG Convention Promo, two players each try to build stronger rows and columns of numbered tiles into an imaginary 4 by 4 grid. At the end of the game, the player with the lowest overall scoring line (based on the four lines each player owns) loses the game.
188389.name: Dragon Master: BGG Convention Promo

188390.name: Enemy Coast Ahead: The Doolittle Raid
188390.description:
Enemy Coast Ahead: The Doolittle Raid uses the game format to explore the first raid on the Japanese home islands by the United States during World War Two. It is a solitaire game challenging the player to conduct a successful mission where the criteria for success is not purely military. The player must organize, equip, and train a squadron of B-25 medium “Mitchell” bombers to attack a distant and rather dangerous target. The game not only covers the raid from launch to landing, it extends the story on both ends. Threatened from the air and from the sea, the player must do his utmost to strike the Japanese capital, avenging the attack on Pearl Harbor, and then land his aircraft safely. If the raid goes poorly it may boost Japanese morale and deflate the mood in the United States. Getting the B-25s close enough to launch is vital, as is the recovery of aircraft and crewmen, but above all, the player’s main dilemma will be secrecy. The risk is great. Failure could mean the loss of an entire squadron, or worse, the sinking of a precious aircraft carrier. Will the Doolittle Raid add to the dismal news of Pearl Harbor, Guam, Wake Island, and Bataan, or will it signal the turning of the tide?

The History
Washington – April 21, 1942: After two days of rumor prompted by Japanese radio broadcasts, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt finally agrees to a press conference. Deftly avoiding difficult questions, he claims insufficient information to neither confirm nor deny the biggest news story of the four month old war. To placate tenacious journalists, however, he tells the press that the attack on Kobe, Osaka, Nagoya, and Tokyo by United States aircraft, was launched from a mysterious base he would only call “Shangri-La,” an imaginary island from the recently published novel Lost Horizon. His impish grin, if not his words, tell the press that the top secret operation dubbed Special Aviation Project Number One has indeed been a success.

That same day China’s foreign minister hands a telegram to Army Air Corps Chief Hap Arnold. It has taken some time to arrive in Washington, an indication that all may not be well with the mission. Dictated two days ago by the commander of that top secret operation, a distraught Lt. Colonel James Doolittle, it reads:

Mission to bomb Tokyo has been accomplished. On entering China we ran into bad weather and it is feared that all planes crashed.

Telegram in hand, Arnold immediately admits to the commander of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that the mission has failed. No bombers have been recovered. After sending that telegram, Doolittle himself expects a court marshall, confiding to his engineer that they’ll tie him to a desk for the rest of the war, if he’s lucky. Days later he is astonished to learn of his promotion to Brigadier General, and even more so when he is notified that the president recommended the Congressional Medal of Honor.

The Doolittle Raid remains an enigmatic and contradictory episode of World War Two, defying easy interpretation even to this day. Was it a victory or a debacle? Was it a minor footnote in the annals of that war or a significant military event? Was it a desperate bid to avenge the attack on Pearl Harbor, or, a harbinger signaling death and horror soon to visit Japanese cities from the sky?

Narrative Sequence
Much like chapters in a story, the game is organized in six narrative segments, chronologically arranged. Each poses its own set of challenges and prompts decisions that establish the environment and conditions of subsequent chapters.

Planning
Naval
Flight
Over Targets
Recovery
Debriefing

Historical Scenarios
Besides play of the full narrative, the game offers a number of historical dissections, each a scenario focusing on a fragment of the raid. They are also a handy way to learn the game, since each scenario uses only part of the rules. For example, Scenario One covers Doolittle’s flight over Tokyo, using only the 8.5x11 Target Map and the Attack Segment. An alternative scenario looks at a night raid by that flight, as Doolittle originally planned it. After playing one or two small scenarios using only the Attack segment’s rules, a larger scenario can be played adding the Flight segment. Graduate next to an even larger scenario that starts with the Naval segment. In this way a player can learn the game in program fashion, little by little, studying the history of the raid by playing it as he learns.

Player Aid Folders: The game comes with several 11” x 17” bi-fold aids allowing the play of each game segment with minimal study of the rule book. The mapsheet is designed to interlock with other game components, including those play aids, in order to make the player’s experience fluid.

188391.name: Game of Thrones - Episode 6: The Ice Dragon

videogameseries.26449: Game of Thrones - A TellTale Game Series

videogamefranchise.26469: A Song of Ice and Fire

188391.description:
The final episode in the tale of House Forrester's struggle, with the continuing search for the North Grove, the defense of Ironwrath, and the effort to pull in reinforcements from King's Landing.

User Summary

188392.name: Karacterz
188392.description:
A new epic fighting card game to experience! Build your own fighter, complete with weapons, armor, masteries and origin stories and fight to see who built the best one! Karacterz features 77 unique artworks of 63 artists from 23 countries. Play with a fresh experience every time.

Build your character to specialize in either Magical, Agility (martial arts) or Physical (medieval warfare), have a combination of two of them or all three! Players also build up their character's combat deck to fight with and buff them up with stats. There is no Life Points or Maximum Health in Karacterz so deal as much damage to your opponents as possible! Player with the least amount of damage on them is the victor.

Karacterz is a great game for gamers of all styles and skill levels. This is a perfect game for skilled gamers to play with more casual gamers. Karacterz features many small game mechanics that interact with each other, perfect for experienced gamers, but not necessary a must to win. Those who find the depth of Karacterz overwhelming need not play with every feature to have a great time and beat up their friends!

Playing with a large group? Karacterz features a Teamwork/Betrayal system that guarantees to make group play interesting and more fun! Wanna check out more about Karacterz? Go to our links!

188393.name: The Original Wing Commander RPG
188393.description:
User summary:

The Original Wing Commander RPG adapts a series of videogames published by Origin to a traditional table-top role-playing game. The implementation is faithful to the flavor of the video games and thus the primary focus of combat is small ship-to-ship dogfights. The rules do provide for person-to-person combat but the options are limited in this regard. The game's setting is derived from several of the video games in the series, not a single title.

188394.name: Penta-Tricks
188394.description:
User summary
ペンタトリックス (Penta-Tricks) is a game about the power struggle between aristocrats in the 14th Century France, during the reign of Louis XIV. It combines trick-taking and area-majority.

During the game, changes occur to both the trick-taking trump and the value of areas for area majority points.

The game has Dice in the suit colours set up on a pentagram showing the value 2 at the start. The trick taking follows the normal pattern, with players following the suit lead if possible and the highest card winning. If there is a Trump suit, highest Trump card will win. But after each trick, the dice values change. The winning suit rises by 1 (or 2 if it was Trump). And one of the dice opposite that winning dice falls by 1. After this change, the lowest dice (if any) now becomes Trump.

But this change in dice values also affects the players' scoring. Before the trick winner adjusts the dice values, the losers place one or two cubes against the dice of the suit they played (or its neighbour). NOTE, the winner of the trick does not get to place cubes, but does choose which dice will drop 1 point. At the end of the round, majority cubes score the face value of the dice (except the Trump die), second most gets half rounded down. Tricks won are also worth 2 points each.

So the game becomes more than just winning tricks. Players want to lose tricks so they can place a cube (2 cubes if you lose on a Trump card) and gain majorities. But they also want to win tricks to control Trump or No Trump and lower the points on another dice.

Publisher's summary
ルイ14世時代のフランスが舞台の、貴族達の権力闘争をモチーフにしたゲームです。
トリックテイキングゲームとエリアマジョリティゲームを一つにまとめたような作りになっています。
トリックテイキングの切り札がゲームの途中で変わります。
エリアマジョリティのエリアの価値もゲームの途中で変わります。

188395.name: Character Sheets
188395.description:
User summary:

Character sheets for The Original Wing Commander RPG were provided in several formats. A blank print-and-use sheet was provided as a large 300 DPI GIF image. Partially automated character sheets were provided in three formats: Lotus 1-2-3, Microsoft Excel, and Claris Works. These three use embedded formulas partially to automate the character creation process.

188396.name: MRPS: Milieu Role Playing System
188396.description:
User summary:

MRPS: Milieu Role Playing System is a light-weight and generic, universal role-playing system. It is adaptable to any genre. Characters have Attributes (for example, Strength and Dexterity) and Skills. Skills are divided into Combat and Non-Combat Skills, the only mechanical difference being that Non-Combat Skills are capped at Level +15 proficiency. A Skill Level of 5 is considered "Qualified" while 8 is considered "Expert". When Skills are used the player rolls 1D20 and adds either their Attribute or Skill modifier, whichever is appropriate. This value must match or exceed a target Difficulty.

The Difficulty is derived from the task's narrative description of Easy, Routine, Moderate, Difficult, Formidable, or Impossible. This description is cross-referenced to the campaign style (Realistic, Cinematic, or Heroic) to obtain the Difficulty, which ranged from 5+ to 30+.

188397.name: Dropout
188397.description:
Welcome to your last semester of college!
Dropout is a humorous take-that card game for up to four players who try to raise their G.P.A in order to graduate.

Unfortunately, there are so many distractions to your studies: parties to attend, movies to watch and beer to drink. Each one of these distractions will lower your G.P.A. However, if you study, do your homework and avoid temptation, you might be able to raise and your G.P.A and graduate!

Each turn players will place activity cards to increase their G.P.A and distraction cards on the other players to lower theirs. After four rounds of triumphs and defeats, one semester has passed.

Earn the highest G.P.A in four semesters and become the one who doesn't Dropout

188398.name: Alakazam!
188398.description:
Welcome to Robert Houdin’s theater! The most famous magicians in the world come here to prove themselves. You will have to show your skills in card, coin and stage magic. Will you gain the audience’s favor or will this be your last performance?

Alakazam! is a fast-paced card game for 2 to 6 players. Players are dealt a hand of cards with a set of three magic tricks in each. In every turn, each player has to play a card that has a better trick than the one performed by the previous player. They must pass if they don't have a card with a better trick.

The first player to perform all his tricks wins the game.

188399.name: All my Friends are Psycho
188399.description:
You always suspected that they were psycho, now it is time to prove it.

In All my Friends are Psycho you become the psychologist and use original designed Rorschach cards to find out just how demented and gross your friends really are.

The Rorschach card deck is set in the middle face down. Flip the same number of cards that you have players, face up.

Without touching the cards, each player chooses an image to analyze keeping their interpretation a secret.

The psychologist picks up the cards and one by one asks each player what they saw. The psychologist has to match the player's interpretation with the correct card.

If the psychologist guesses correctly, both the player and psychologist gets 1 sanity point. If not, they score 1 psycho point.

Each player takes turns being the psychologist. After this the sanity and psycho points are added up. The player that has the closest number of sanity and psycho points (balances out) wins.

The game comes with 27 Rorschach cards and requires a genuine, original (neither genuine nor original) pad and pen.

188400.name: Medieval Might
188400.description:
In Medieval Might, two generals are pitted against each other in a battle. Each leads their army against each other to become the supreme commander.

Players take turns placing their units, represented by cards, on the battlefield. Each card builds up the strength of their forces, and use tactics to weaken their opponent's forces.

Use your knights and banner-men to greatly increase your strength, while deploying your scouts to gain an advantage over your opponent. If they start to take the lead, use your marksman to eliminate high value targets or ambush their forces to reduce their effectiveness.

The army with the higher value at the end of that round is the victor of that round. The game ends when one player loses two rounds, and the winner is crowned the supreme commander

188401.name: MATCH!
188401.description:
MATCH! is an abstract family game in where you compete to build chains out of matches.

Search simultaneously for matching cards, which use the Stroop effect, a scientific principle that creates interference in the player's reaction time.

Don't let the cards manipulate you as you build the most chains of cards before all the matches are gone.

The player that makes the most matches wins.

Download Print & Play on:
http://www.trickzbunny.com/match.html

188402.name: Mad House
188402.description:
There's a house filled with hungry zombies and your team is in the middle of it!!!

Around each corner there are different terrors. Super fast zombies, giant zombies and viscous stalkers are the least of your worries.

Mad House is a nail biting card strategy game for up to 5 players. It features a unique Noise Tracking mechanic; if you're team makes too much noise they will be attacked by horde of zombies!

The only way to survive is to keep everyone alive. Kill the required number of zombies to escape this Nightmare ...

Can you escape the Mad House?!

188403.name: Zaon
188403.description:
User summary:

Zaon was professionally developed and was planned for commercial release. It went through at least seven major playtest revisions between 1997 and 2002 when the "Errata Version 7.0 Rewrite" version was released for playtest. Shortly thereafter the publisher discontinued development and the game was never commercially released. The final playtest version is complete and playable, missing only final art. The cartography is complete and impressive, and development standards are very high. However, Zaon is a peculiar and atypical role-playing game that uses non-standard terminology and procedures that apparently was intended to support a line of licensed toys and other products.

188404.name: Zaon Digital Accessories
188404.description:
User summary:

Zaon was supported by the period release of digital accessories which were made available for free download. Notable accessories include:


Character Record Sheet, two-page PDF, distinctive design
Sector 48-735, High-Resolution JPG Map
Sector 52, High-Resolution JPG Map
Galaxy Map, one-page PDF map
Quantum Corridors and CGates, one-page PDF map


Note that the maps are reproduced in the core book, but at a lower resolution. As the Sector maps, in particular, have an incredible amount of detail the high resolution versions are quite helpful.

188405.description:
From the publisher:

The Nieuport 28 was a French biplane fighter flown during World War I, designed by Gustave Delage. Owing its lineage to the successful line of sesquiplane fighters as the Nieuport 17, the Nieuport 28 continued a similar design philosophy of a lightweight and highly maneuverable aircraft.

A shortage of SPADs led to the production of Nieuport 28s. It became the first aircraft to see operational service with an American fighter squadron. It was flown by famous aces such as Ralph A. O’Neil, Harold E. Hartney and Edward Rickenbacker.

Designed to be used with the popular air combat game system created by Andrea Angiolino and Pier Giorgio Paglia, each WW1 Wings of Glory Airplane Pack is a ready-to-play model, painted and assembled, 100% compatible with any other WW1 Wings of Glory game product. In each pack you will find all you need to play with the airplane: a special base with gaming stats, a variable altitude flying stand, and a specific deck of maneuver cards.
188405.name: Wings of Glory: World War 1 – Nieuport Ni.28

121016.name: Wings of Glory: WW1 Airplane Packs

boardgamefamily.55: Wings of Glory / Wings of War

188406.description:
From the publisher:

The Macchi M.5 was an Italian single-seat fighter flying boat, designed and built by Nieuport-Macchi at Varese. It was extremely maneuverable and agile and matched the land-based aircraft it had to fight.

The M.5 was operated by five Italian maritime patrol squadrons as a fighter and convoy escort. By the end of World War I, these aircraft were flown by both United States Navy and United States Marine Corps airmen. The three versions of the airplane proposed include the model flown by the Italian pilot Domenico Arcidiacono, an American plane flown by Willis B. Haviland and a captured Austrian plane piloted by Friedrich Welker

Designed to be used with the popular air combat game system created by Andrea Angiolino and Pier Giorgio Paglia, each WW1 Wings of Glory Airplane Pack is a ready-to-play model, painted and assembled, 100% compatible with any other WW1 Wings of Glory game product. In each pack you will find all you need to play with the airplane: a special base with gaming stats, a variable altitude flying stand, and a specific deck of maneuver cards.
188406.name: Wings of Glory: World War 1 – Macchi M.5

121016.name: Wings of Glory: WW1 Airplane Packs

boardgamefamily.55: Wings of Glory / Wings of War

188407.description:
From the publisher:

The Hannover CL.III was a German military aircraft of World War I. It was a two-seat multi-role aircraft, primarily used as a ground attack machine.

Like the other Hannover "light-C-class", or "CL" designated aircraft, it included an unusual biplanar tail, allowing for a greater firing arc for the tail gunner. Until the introduction of this model, such tails had only been used on larger aircraft. The Hannover CL.IIIa in WW1 Wings of Glory is presented in versions flown by Rudolf Hager/Otto Weber and Johann Baur/Georg von Hengel, as well a Luftstreitkräfte model.

Designed to be used with the popular air combat game system created by Andrea Angiolino and Pier Giorgio Paglia, each WW1 Wings of Glory® Airplane Pack is a ready-to-play model, painted and assembled, 100% compatible with any other WW1 Wings of Glory game product. In each pack you will find all you need to play with the airplane: a special base with gaming stats, a variable altitude flying stand, and a specific deck of maneuver cards.
188407.name: Wings of Glory: World War 1 – Hannover CL.IIIa

121016.name: Wings of Glory: WW1 Airplane Packs

boardgamefamily.55: Wings of Glory / Wings of War

188408.name: Zombiepocalypse
188408.description:
User summary:

Characters are tracked on a character "sheet" which is about the size of a 3" x 5" card. Characters have a "Player's Option" which is a Skill the character is good at (examples include "knowing how to pick a lock", "being a better shot with a pistol", or "knowing how to fly a plane"). Otherwise, characters only need track wounds, ammunition, and inventory. Note the Player's Option can be determined prior to play or at any time during play - but once it is declared ("invested", in game terms) it cannot be changed.

Although the game's central action involves combat (usually with zombies), the combat mechanics are simple. The rules favor a cinematic, exciting pace to realism. Players roll D6 and compare the result to an action table (which is easily memorized). Generally, 4-6 indicates a hit. Damage also is resolved with a D6 and action table (again, easily memorized). It is suggested the game be played "tactically", with a map and miniatures - the rules suppose a hex grid.

The basic HTML rules include various supporting pages such as a bestiary (Basic Zombie, Strong Zombie, Grabber Zombie, Runner Zombie, Creeper Zombie, Leaper Zombie, Screecher Zombie, Thrower Zombie, Lurker Zombie, Pus Zombie, Stench Zombie, Titan Zombie, Feral Zombie, and a handful of boring non-zombies).

188409.name: Zombiepocalypse Accessories
188409.description:
User summary:

The game's web site provides several downloadable print-and-use accessories to aid game play. These include:


Player's Cheat Sheet (two-page PDF for in-game reference)
Game Tokens (two-page PDF with color paper miniatures and condition tokens)
Player Character Record Sheet (one-page PDF with four sheets)
Zombiepocalypse Logo


With a game master familiar with the rules, players could easily be in the game with the Player's Cheat Sheet in perhaps five minutes.

188410.description:
Promo character card that comes packaged inside every English copy of Bottlecap Vikings.

ICE VIKING

Character Ability: When ANY player ships goods, you may freeze one good at it's current selling price. The rest of the market resolves around the frozen good as normal.

Flavor Text: Yes, He carries an axe with him to negotiations. But give him half a chance and he'll talk your ear off about business - hostile takeover this, frozen assets that... - Dockmaster Schlibble

THE WHARFS (on the back of every character)

Character Ability: Gain 2 good of different types -or- Buy a building.

Flavor Text:
"This may sound crazy but, don't try to split up the orders! You know how terrible those ogres are at counting? Last week I told one of em to take three barrels of fish to the pier. The thick brute took all fourteen! Best just point at a load of one type of good and tell em to take em all. It'll save us all a headache. At the most we'll lose a unit or two. Trust me it'll be worth it." - Dockmaster Schlibble

"Those darned Gnolls will steal anything that isn't nailed down! If you have maxed out your storehouse's room for any of the goods types, you'll have to leave the rest outside. Don't expect to see them in the morning." - Constable O'Brady
188410.name: Harbour: Ice Viking

188411.name: Zombies!!! RPG
188411.description:
User summary:

Twilight Creations published the best-selling Zombies!!! board game in 2001. The board game has several aspects bordering on traditional role-playing, leading the author to adapt the game's basic concepts to more traditional table-top role-play. The game transpires on a playing area made of tiles that are placed by the Zombie Master as they are explored by the characters.

Characters have Statistics (Attributes) with randomly determined values, including Health (2D10+10), Muscles (1D6+1), Brains (1D6+1), and Aim (1D6+1). Atypically, when health reaches 1 the character is unconscious; when it reaches 0 the character is dead. Characters otherwise need only perform inventory management and "Point" tracking. During play characters gain Points and may also spend them to alter narrative events. Movement is derived from the board-game heritage: characters roll 1D6 and may move up to that many spaces. Combat is a simple D10 + modifier vs. D10 + modifier. Damage ranges from 1D6 (crowbar) to 2D10+5 (flame thrower) - explosives do even more.

Because of the nature of the game, character mortality is high. The game mechanics essentially presuppose brief campaigns, offering only limited options for multiple sessions and character advancement.

188413.description: Wormhole! is a space themed board game for up to 8 players that turns the traditional rules of game play inside out. Everyone starts out at the edge of the board on a spiral track. Every turn you roll the dice, move closer to doom and draw a card. That card may be good, it may be bad, but it will certainly be unpleasant for someone. Red event cards go into effect immediately and may move you forward or back, swap you with the nearest ship or even make you take another turn. Blue mass cards are...mass cards. Mass is also the most common card type in the deck and comes in 25, 50, 75, and 100 unit variants. Mass is bad, because for every 100 mass you accumulate you have to roll another die on your turn. So if you’ve got 300 mass sitting in front of you, you’re rolling 4 dice every turn (that's your original die plus 3 more). And that’s just not going to end well. Green action cards are like the red event cards, but you can hold onto them and use them at your discretion. Use one to send your highest mass card to the person behind you...or if you happen to be that person behind you can use a different one to dodge that mass and let it keep on heading back. There’s even an action card that will let you skip your own turn! When a player inevitably reaches the center of the wormhole, they are out. Flung into the deepest recesses of time and space most likely. When that happens, they mix up their remaining action cards with their mass cards and each remaining player takes one at random (going in order along the track). Play continues until only one player is left on the board, allowing them to safely escape the wormhole and making them the winner.
188413.name: Wormhole!

188414.name: S.O.S. in the City of the Dead
188414.description:
User summary:

This adventure includes tile layouts (it supposes tiles from the board game will be available), encounter locations and types, and notes regarding setup. The scenario requires the characters to arrive at a specified rendezvous point by a deadline. The mission is assumed to fail if the deadline passes.

188415.name: Crop Circles
188415.description:
Crop Circles is an abstract puzzle game for 2-6 players. Taking the role of aliens warning Earthlings of impending doom, players etch glyphs into crop fields with their spaceships, according to changing rules about adjacency between glyph shapes and glyph shading in order to score points for effectively following the rules set forth by the Intergalactic Communications Council.

Each turn, a player places any number of glyph tiles from behind their screen onto the board in an unbroken straight line, connected to glyph tiles that are already on the board. That player scores points for the sum of the values of only the glyphs played (affected by on-board multiplier squares) multiplied by the number of glyph tiles already on the board that were adjacent to their play. Thus, a long string of glyph tiles played parallel to a previous play can net massive points, so players must balance taking advantage of opportunities for huge points with preventing such opportunities for other players. Finally, that player then draws exactly three new glyph tiles either among five face-up glyph tiles next to the play area or from the bag of remaining glyph tiles, regardless of how many they played on their turn, as long as they played at least one glyph.

Glyphs come in four shapes (circles, squares, triangles, and stars) and four shadings (empty, solid, striped, and crossed). Each shading is permitted only to certain shapes, and when a player places glyph tiles on the board, they must satisfy the requirements of both the glyphs being places and the glyphs they are playing adjacent to. The more complex a shading, the more difficult it is to place on the board and the more points it is worth: empty glyphs have no restrictions about what shapes they may be placed adjacent to and are worth only one point; solid glyphs may be adjacent to only three of the four shapes and are worth two points; striped glyphs may be adjacent to only two of four shapes and are worth three points; and crossed glyphs may be adjacent only to a single shape and is worth four points! However, the four active rule cards that determine these permitted adjacencies will get replaced throughout a game, providing new opportunities to play glyphs. Players must plan ahead, acquire useful glyphs, and play them on the most opportune turns.
